texts.label: text
texts.orig: Running OS X 10.6.3?  William Fennie  found a fix on Google Groups .
texts.text: Running OS X 10.6.3?  William Fennie  found a fix on Google Groups .

texts.label: text
texts.orig: First off, credit for this fix on  OS X 10.6.2  goes to  Geoff Watts  from his  two   tweets .
texts.text: First off, credit for this fix on  OS X 10.6.2  goes to  Geoff Watts  from his  two   tweets .

texts.label: text
texts.orig: If you're using Snow Leopard, you'll find that the current version of MacFusion refuses to complete a connection to a remote server. You can fix this in two steps:
texts.text: If you're using Snow Leopard, you'll find that the current version of MacFusion refuses to complete a connection to a remote server. You can fix this in two steps:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Second, open System Preferences and then open the MacFUSE pane. Check the “Show Beta Versions” box and click “Check For Updates”. Go ahead and update MacFUSE.
texts.text: Second, open System Preferences and then open the MacFUSE pane. Check the “Show Beta Versions” box and click “Check For Updates”. Go ahead and update MacFUSE.

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Third, open up a terminal and do the following:
texts.text: Third, open up a terminal and do the following:

texts.label: text
texts.orig: Your MacFusion installation should now be working on Snow Leopard. I've tested SSH and FTP connectivity so far, and they both appear to be working. Thanks again to Geoff for the fix!
texts.text: Your MacFusion installation should now be working on Snow Leopard. I've tested SSH and FTP connectivity so far, and they both appear to be working. Thanks again to Geoff for the fix!
